item.title: Analyzing Commuting Patterns in Ontario
item.description: I was inspired by David Robinson’s latest webcast in which he made a heatmap of French train delays using geom_tile and wanted to try it out for myself. In this week's #tidytuesday screencast, I analyze delays in French train stations ðŸ‡«ðŸ‡·ðŸš„ I show how to create heatmaps of delays (inspired by @noccaea!), and embarrass myself with even the simplest French pronunciationshttps://t.co/zBrkIkdcCz #rstats pic.twitter.com/RI7ZpxV89X — David Robinson (@drob) February 26, 2019

item.title: Mapping 2016 Census Data
item.description: The 2016 Census has a lot of useful data to be examined. Luckily, there’s a great R package cancensus that let’s you access and map the data easily. You can use get_census to download the table and geographic features you need. sault_income <- get_census(dataset='CA16', regions=list(CMA="35590"), vectors="v_CA16_2397", level='DA', quiet = TRUE, geo_format = 'sf', labels = 'short') The dataframe is ready to be mapped using ggplot or leaflet if you want to be interactive.
